justification: The article states, “One of the paradigms used to study cognitive control is the Stroop task, where participants are instructed to name the hue of a color word … while inhibiting their automatic tendency to read the word.”

It notes, “Similarly, in the Eriksen flanker task, participants are asked to report the identity of a target stimulus … while overcoming their automatic tendency to respond instead to the distractors,” presenting the task as a paradigm for cognitive control.

The paper describes that Lin et al. used “a visual search task in which [participants] gradually learned to allocate their attention to locations whose color predicted the appearance of the target,” linking the task to measuring how people control attention.
When discussing Krebs et al. (2010), the article explains that a “color-word Stroop task” was employed to study how reward modulates adaptations to conflict, using it to index interference control.

Referring to Braem et al. (2012), it says participants performed “a Flanker task … to name the color of a central square…,” which the authors analyze as a measure of interference control and its learning dynamics.
